messageBody:
Thanks for your quick response. Good point about
Eat/Ooze. Keep proofing.
I use Fontographer, running in MAC OS9. It is really a
pleasure. I should be able to generate both Windows
and Truetype fonts when the tweaking is done.

--- oliver langan <oliverlangan@...> wrote:

>
> Just downloaded it, haven't read it yet. My first
> response though is that the font is
> beautiful! Difficult at first to read, for those of
> us accustomed to jerome and the similar
> font offerings; but much much better proportioned
> for 'typeset' text.
>
> The only immediate problem I foresee is the only
> slight difference between Eat and Ooze.
>
> Based on these proportions, I would love to also see
> a slightly-less-serif version :) But
> heck, I can't wait to get my hands on this version!
> What font tools did you use?
>
> oliver
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "mcbroom1946"
> <mcbroom1946@y...> wrote:
> >
> > After promising to do so in a long-ago previous
> episode, I have finally
> > completed a new font to add to the Read Alphabet
> collection. But before
> > posting it, I thought it best to explain my
> intentions, and get your collective
> > feedback.
> >
> > Doing some frequency work on QS, I was looking at
> whole stories and essays
> > printed in existing fonts (Jerome and its
> variations), and saw in a sudden
> > blinding revelation that the original QS script
> --- aping, as it does, our Mr.
> > Read's elegant hand --- was in fact not
> appropriate for large, printed bodies of
> > text.
> >
> > For, even though I love Read for its logical
> shapes, its grace, and its pleasure
> > in handwriting, I feel now that for an alphabet to
> prosper, it must be able to
> > morph itself into alternative fonts that can
> either whisper or shout, waltz or
> > march, wax poetic or prosaic as the need arises. I
> mean, would anyone read
> > the Times every morning (or an Agatha Christie
> every night) if they were
> > printed in Gothic script or Spencerian penmanship?
> >
> > Let's face it. After almost 40 years before the
> world, QS has not "taken off"
> > except among we happy few. Why is that? Is there
> something we could learn
> > from traditional typography? After all, though our
> fore-fathers bollixed up any
> > natural correspondence of shapes and sounds, they
> might not have been
> > total fools.
> >
> > So I looked at the classic typefaces that we have
> been employing in Western
> > printing for the last 200 years, and wondered if
> their styles and shapes could
> > be transformed to capture the essence of Mr.
> Read's originally-hand-drawn
> > characters. And I was amazed to discover that,
> yes, I think they can.
> >
> > My new QS font is based upon a font called
> "Century Schoolbook," a face
> > which all Americans of a certain age should
> remember from their first reading
> > lessons: "See Dick run. Run, Dick, run!" I
> thought it would make an
> > appropriate "primer" for learning to "read Read."
> >
> > I have just posted a brief "Fish Story" in the
> Text folder of the Files Section,
> > which I would hope you all will have the time and
> curiosity to peruse. Please
> > let me know if it "communicates" to you. If you
> can, try viewing it at different
> > sizes too - as if you were reading the morning
> paper, instead of a bronze
> > plaque.
> >
> > After your feedback, I will post the completed
> font or - depending on your
> > learned opinions - just go sulking off into the
> internet night. It's up to you all.
>
>
>
>


=====
